title: Dutch pointlessness
content:
Can someoen translate this for me, it's Sambal bij by Ome Henk and understand just enough of it to be curious.

And I want to waste your time.

"Laatst ging ik in mijn eentje
bij ons naar de chinees
dat is weer eens wat anders dan een brootje warrem vlees
Afijn dus ik ga zitten en ik zeg tegen dat figuur
hey goochem zet dat gas es an, onder het frituur

Mischien was hij een beetje doof want hij verstond het niet
dus ik roep keihard OBER een zakje friet!!
Met flink wat mayonaise, doe een brood je ei
Graag een beetje snel ja, weet je wat hij zei????

Sambal bij? lekkel lekkel
Sambal bij? lekkel
Sambal bij? lekkel lekkel
Sambal bij? lekkel

Ik heb uren zitten wachten, mijn geduld dat raakte op
Ik pakte toen mijn stoel en smeet hem naar zijn kop
Opeens greep hij een zwaard en daar zwaaide hij mee in't rond
Dus ik roep keihard TJAKKA en schop hem voor zijn kont.

Sambal bij? lekkel lekkel
Sambal bij? lekkel
Sambal bij? lekkel lekkel
Sambal bij? lekkel

Ik pakte snel mijn bord en smeet het door het raam,
de loempia's vlogen heen en weer en die chinees er achter aan
Nou toen brak de pleuris uit de keuken die liep leeg
en iedereen liep te rossen, tot buiten in de steeg.

Sambal bij? lekkel lekkel
Sambal bij? lekkel
Sambal bij? lekkel lekkel
Sambal bij? lekkel "


Thankyou in advance, at least for reading this far. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-grin.gif[/img]

[img]http://img.photobucket.com/albums/v499/Nevad/menbun.gif[/img]

Cute bunny!

title: Re: Dutch pointlessness
content:
Okay, gimme a sec. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]


I recently went to a chinese restaurant on my own
That's quite a difference from a roll of warm meat (no idea how it's called in English, lol)
Anyway I took a seat and I said to that guy
Hey smartass turn on the heat on your (frituur? [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-dead.gif[/img] )

I think he was a dit deaf because he didn't understand
so I yelled out loud WAITER gimme some french fries!
With lots of mayonnaise, and some bread with eggs on it
And be a bit quick about it, well, do you know what he said???

Sambal with that? Vely vely nice
Sambal with that? Vely nice
etc.

I had been waiting, and I ran out of patience
Then I just grabbed my chair and smashed it against his head
Suddenly he grabbed a sword and he was swinging it around
So I yelled out TJAKKA and kicked his ass.

Sambal with that? Vely vely nice
Sambal with that? Vely nice
etc.

I quickly grabbed my plate and threw it through the window,
the spring rolls were flying around the place and behind that the chinese guy
Well then all hell broke loose and the kitchen became empty
and everybody was fighting, even outside, in the alley.

Sambal with that? Vely vely nice
Sambal with that? Vely nice
etc.


Kinda racistic, but pretty funny/ridiculous, too. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-rolleyes.gif[/img] ____________
Don't think of me as an ordinary man.

Even though I am an ordinary man.

Ah, [url=http://DaVince.sitesled.com/]site.[/url]

title: Re: Dutch pointlessness
content:
'Sabal bij' sounds like slang.

Tell me, what is the difference between 'beet' and 'beetje'; 'ander' and 'anders'; 'begrijp' and 'vestond'; and 'achter' and 'Achterlijk'?

Also, I think 'brrotje warem vlees' is best substituted as 'hotdog' [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-grin.gif[/img]
[img]http://img.photobucket.com/albums/v499/Nevad/menbun.gif[/img]

Cute bunny!

title: Re: Dutch pointlessness
content:
Sambal bij is actually broken Dutch. "Would you like sambal with that?" becomes "Sambal with that?" or something. It's supposed to sound somewhat Chinese (just like saying "lekkel" instead of "lekker", which means something that tastes nice).

Een beetje = a bit in English, where "beet" would translate as "bite".

"ander" is another, "anders" is different.

"Begrijpen" and "verstaan" both mean to understand, but the difference lies in the meaning of "to understand". "Begrijpen" is more about getting what someone means, whereas "verstaan" is more in the meaning of being able to understand a language (or to hear what someone says).

"achter" is behind (not the ass kind of thing, lol), "achterlijk" means "idiot". [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-cheeky.gif[/img]

And a hot dog is just a hot dog here. I do know that the meat on a broodje warm vlees is in slices though, not like a sausage.____________
Don't think of me as an ordinary man.

Even though I am an ordinary man.

Ah, [url=http://DaVince.sitesled.com/]site.[/url]

title: Re: Dutch pointlessness
content:
Yes, but a hotdog sounds very much like warm meat on a bun to me, and there are so many english equivalents. (We have the steak sandwich for example, hot rolls, savoury slice... [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-drool.gif[/img] )

I have noticed a lot of uses of the suffixes -tje and -lijk; are they like the english suffixes -et and -like? (I.e bloog and blooglet, life and lieflike)

Also, what does 'tjakka' mean?

Thanks.
[img]http://img.photobucket.com/albums/v499/Nevad/menbun.gif[/img]

Cute bunny!

title: Re: Dutch pointlessness
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]I have noticed a lot of uses of the suffixes -tje and -lijk; are they like the english suffixes -et and -like? (I.e bloog and blooglet, life and lieflike)[hr][/quote]

-je is a Dutch innovation to say that an object is small it can only be connected with a noun. The Dutch word for small can also be used the same way as in English and even in combination without changing the meaning. Sometimes, probably for pronunciation matters, a t is added to the suffix and sometimes the root of the noun is made longer.

Examples: E-D
meisje - little girl
klokje - little clock
kleine klok - little clock
klein meisjes - little girl
koninginnetje (koningin) - little queen
gitaartje (gitaar) little guitar

-like is a little bit harder to explain it's a suffix that can make a noun an adjective.
example: gevaar (danger) ---.> gevaarlijke man (dangerous man). It can also be connected with the predicate.
example: rijkelijk belonen (to reward generously)
Sometimes the adjective has little to with the root.
example: achter means behind while achterlijk means ridiculous.

[quote]Quote:[hr]Also, what does 'tjakka' mean? [hr][/quote]
Tjakka is word made up by someone who's name should not be spoken. The best word I can think of to compare it with is 'yeah' or maybe better 'hell yeah'. It's a word to express enthousiasme.

-----------------

Ridiculous or stupid sound much the same to me, ridiculous=achterlijk is a little bit stronger than stupid=stom.
It certainly doesn't mean backwards, you're confusing is probably caused by the root achter=behind/back which can lead to many words like achterste=a**/back, achteren=backyard.-----------------

title: Re: Dutch pointlessness

Well... "Vond" IS valid... In some cases.

to find - found - found, right? Well, you have "I found" and "I have found", and in Dutch you say "ik vond" and "ik heb gevonden". So for "lost & found" you actually use the third form of "to find" in Dutch...____________

title: Re: Dutch pointlessness
content:
Gelezen, gegeten, gekregen, gegeven. Those are called "sterke werkwoorden" (strong verbs).

Strong verbs often end with -en, while weak verbs end with -t or -d. Gegooid (thrown), gemaakt (made), gedanst.

I forgot how to determine whether a verb is strong or weak. Learn it per verb, I guess. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-cheeky.gif[/img] ____________

title: Ah
content:
I just love the dutch words for well.. words.

Werkwoorden and bijwoorden; such lovely and descriptive terms!

But I mean; it's not the strength that gets me; but those simple words that don't make sense; like start; beginnen, begon, is begonnen or prove; bewijzen, bewees, heeft bewezen. They make terribly little sense to me!

title: Re: Ah
content:
They do make sense, they just use some different grammar rules the English language doesn't have.

The Dutch language is weird. Get used to it. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

Why you even want to learn it beats me though, serves almost no practical use outside the Netherlands (and some Dutch-speaking countries) as far as I know. Then again, aren't there plenty of Dutch-speaking people in New Zealand?____________
